items.description: Lower River Irwell catchment including areas in Greater Manchester

floodArea.county: Bolton, Bury, Manchester, Oldham, Rochdale, Salford, Tameside, Trafford

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Irwell due to heavy rainfall.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the Rivers Irk and Medlock, Wince and Worsley Brooks and their tributaries from 07:00 AM on 23/07/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
This flood alert has been issued in response to rising river levels on the River Calder between Todmorden and Brighouse. Today and throughout tomorrow, Sunday 23rd July 2023, persistent rainfall is forecast, with a spell of heavier rain expected tonight. River levels are currently forecast to peak in Todmorden tomorrow between 03:00 AM and 08:00 AM and predicted to peak downstream in Brighouse around 10:00 AM to 12 noon. This persistent rain could lead to flooding of low-lying land and localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue widespread flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated after 06:00 AM on 23rd July 2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message:
This flood alert is being issued ahead of heavy and persistent rain expected tonight and into tomorrow, Sunday 23 July 2023. Following todayâ€™s rainfall, small watercourses in the Ings Beck catchment are likely to react readily to this further rainfall. River levels are forecast to peak at Westgate around 04:00 tomorrow, and are likely to remain high through the day. This persistent rain could lead to localised surface water flooding and flooding of low-lying land. We are not expecting to issue flood warnings but are closely monitoring the situation. Trash screens have been cleared and flood defences checked. There are currently no concerns about Oakenshaw Beck although we will see high levels on the Calder through tomorrow. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated after 06:00 on 23rd July 2023, or as the situation changes.

"River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible and is forecast to begin from midnight, tonight, 22/07/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
  We expect river levels to remain high for the next 3 or 4 days 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 23/07/23, or as the situation changes."

River levels will rise steadily on the River Wyre, River Brock due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Wyre, Calder and Brock and other watercourses from Abbeystead to Catterall including Scorton, Garstang, Bilsborrow, Ainspool and Churchtown.
Flooding is possible at Rivers Wyre, Calder and Brock and other watercourses from Abbeystead to Catterall including Scorton, Garstang, Bilsborrow, Ainspool and Churchtown from 07:00 AM on 23/07/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.
River levels are expected to remain high throughout the morning on 23/07/2023.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

Areas most at risk include River Wyre, River Cocker, Pilling Water and other watercourses from Catterall to Fleetwood, including St Michaels and Great Eccleston and Preesall.
Flooding is possible at River Wyre, River Cocker, Pilling Water and other watercourses from Catterall to Fleetwood, including St Michaels and Great Eccleston and Preesall from 07:00 AM on 23/07/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This flood alert has been issued in response to rising river levels on the River Calder between Mirfield and Methley. Today and throughout tomorrow, Sunday 23rd July 2023, persistent rainfall is forecast, with a spell of heavier rain expected tonight. River levels are currently forecast to peak tomorrow, in Mirfield around 15:00 and then downstream through Wakefield around 17:30. This persistent rain could lead to flooding of low-lying land and localised surface water flooding. We are not currently expecting to issue flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated after 06:00 on 23rd July 2023 or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Calder and River Hyndburn due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Calder, Brun, Don and Pendlewater, from Laneshaw Bridge to the river Ribble including Trawden, Burnley, Nelson, Colne, Accrington and Whalley.
Flooding is possible at Rivers Calder, Hyndburn, Brun, Don and Pendlewater, from Laneshaw Bridge to the river Ribble including Trawden, Burnley, Nelson, Colne, Accrington and Whalley from 03:00 AM on 23/07/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels will rise steadily on the River Ribble and River Darwen due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton.
Flooding is possible at River Ribble from Samlesbury and the River Darwen from Darwen including Blackburn, Preston, Walton-Le-Dale, Pleasington and Higher Walton from 03:00 AM on 23/07/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the morning.
River levels are expected to remain high.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 08:00 AM on 23/07/2023, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert is being issued ahead of heavy rain expected tonight and further persistent rainfall forecast into tomorrow, Sunday 23 July 2023. Following the wet weather on Saturday, local watercourses in the Earby Beck catchment are likely to react readily to this further rainfall. River levels are currently forecast to peak in Earby tomorrow, around 05:00 for Earby Beck and 08:00 for the New Cut, with levels likely to remain relatively high through the day. 
This persistent rain could lead to localised surface water flooding and flooding of low lying land. We are not currently expecting to issue flood warnings but will be closely monitoring the situation. 
Please stay aware of your surroundings and do not put yourself at risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
For a more detailed weather forecast for your area please see the Met Office website at www.metoffice.gov.uk.
This message will be updated after 06:00 on 23rd July 2023 or as the situation changes.
